title: Mortgage-holders should get ready for rising interest rates - ASB
text:
Mortgage-holders should get ready for rising interest rates - ASB SUSAN EDMUNDS Last updated 14:42, February 15 2017 SUPPLIED 
ASB's chief executive says the bank has experienced market headwinds. 
Borrowers can expect to pay more for their mortgages over the coming months. 
ASB has reported a profit of $525 million for the six months ended December, up 11 per cent on the same time the year before. 
The bank's chief executive, Barbara Chapman, said the market was changing. 
The official cash rate is unlikely to rise this year but banks are facing higher funding costs and other pressures, which are expected to flow through to the rates they charge customers. 
Longer-term interest rates have already moved markedly higher. 
READ MORE: OCR may stay at 1.75pc until 2020, but mortgage rates could be trumped by Trump 
Chapman said the market was challenging. 
The bank's cash net interest margin, the difference between what it charges for lending and pays for deposits, decreased by 17 basis points to 2.21 per cent. 
Chapman said that reflected higher costs associated with wholesale funding and increased costs relating to customers breaking fixed rate loans. 
"As customers take advantage of the current low interest rate environment we are seeing a continued preference for lower margin fixed rate loans," Chapman said. Ad Feedback 
"At the same time, banks now are facing a changing dynamic around the increasing volume and cost of international funding needed to meet local lending requirements. With levels of local deposits failing to keep pace with the amount of lending banks are doing, the increased use of offshore funding has increased funding costs, reducing our net interest margin." 
She said there had been pressure on funding costs as off-shore borrowing became more expensive due to increasing volatility in international markets. 
She said interest rate costs were likely to rise over the next 12 months as banks had to go off-shore for funding because customers wanted to borrow more than they wanted to deposit with the bank. 
"We have to go off-shore to hedge the gap," she said. 
That increase in costs could be expected to flow through to retail rates. 
Commentators have said banks are getting tougher with their lending criteria, particularly for lending to property developers and investors. 
Chapman said the bank wanted to support customers but was also looking at deals closely because there was such demand for money. 
She said the result was a solid one for ASB. - Stuff
